instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-2850: What is 820-2850? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U7000: What is U7000? U7000 refers to the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging IC on Macbooks from 2008-2012.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP5V_S0: What is PP5V_S0? PP5V_S0 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S0 working state..
definitions.PPVCORE_S0_CPU: What is PPVCORE_S0_CPU? This is the primary power rail for the CPU that powers the CPU, known as CPU vcore. Without this, the machine will be braindead. .
definitions.SMC_ONOFF_L: What is SMC_ONOFF_L? SMC_ONOFF_L tells the computer that the power button has been pressed when it is low, _L means signal is asserted when it is low voltage. .
definitions.ALL_SYS_PWRGD: What is ALL_SYS_PWRGD? ALL_SYS_PWRGD is present when PP1V8_S3, PP5V_S3, PP1V2_S3, PP1V05_S0, PP5V_S0, PP3V3_S0, & PP1V5_S0 are present and working. If any of these rails is not working, ALL_SYS_PWRGD will be pulled down and the machine will not turn on. .
definitions.PLT_RESET_L: What is PLT_RESET_L? PLT_RESET_L is platform reset, this signal keeps the system from POSTing. _L means the signal is asserted when its voltage is low. .
definitions.C9560: What is C9560? Tantalum capacitor on 820-2850 logic board that often dies and causes intermittent power to framebuffer PP1V8R1V55_S0GPU_ISNS and PP1V8R1V55_S0GPU_ISNS_R rail, causing GPU kernel panics. Replace with non-tantalum if machine is having random black screen or kernel panics.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green light. No fan spin.
threads.message:
Board looks very clean.

<SIGNAL>PPVCORE_S0_CPU</SIGNAL> = 0v and diode mode = 057.

<SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL> = cycling. <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> cycling.

If removed F7040, pin 1 cycling

<CHIP>U7000</CHIP>
pin 3 = 4v
pin 14 = 3.3v 
pin 27-28 = 20.8ohm
pin 17-18 = 3.3ohm

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green light. No fan spin.
threads.message: Post basic voltages for <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>; pins 1, 2, 3. 9, 12, 13, 14, 15, 17, 19, 20, 27.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green light. No fan spin.
threads.message:
1 = 15v cycling (measured at <RESISTOR>R7086</RESISTOR> pin 2)
2 = 16.5v
3 = 4v
9 = 0.03v
12 = 3.4v
13 = 3.4v
14 = 3.3v
15 = 0.05v
17 = 12.5v cycling
19 = 5v
20 = 5v
27 = 16.3v cycling

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green light. No fan spin.
threads.message:
How is cycling <CAPACITOR>C7040</CAPACITOR> voltage?
Can you post some values?

Just in case, change <TRANSISTOR>Q7080</TRANSISTOR>/85.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green light. No fan spin.
threads.message:
removed 7040 pin 1 = 12.5v cycling = <CAPACITOR>C7040</CAPACITOR> voltage.

<TRANSISTOR>Q7080</TRANSISTOR> pin 1 is 16-16.3v which goes into <RESISTOR>R7085</RESISTOR> pin 1 but pin 2 is cycling... bad <TRANSISTOR>Q7085</TRANSISTOR>?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green light. No fan spin.
threads.message:
Cycling...
Can you post the values???
0-12.6V is not the same as 12.3-12.6V, for example.

Did you try fake charger, or lab PSU.
Also, this board requires 85W charger, if battery is not connected.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green light. No fan spin.
threads.message:
85w genuine used. Did not try fake charger

it is 0-12.6v cycling.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green light. No fan spin.
threads.message: Put back F7040 and test again.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green light. No fan spin.
threads.message:
ok i dont know why.. but i put back F7040, on real 85W, now fan spin and stop, DELAY, spin and stop....sometimes the delay seems longer and sometime shorter..

With a fake charger, voltage at F7040 is 12.5v, no fan spin.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green light. No fan spin.
threads.message:
Steady 12.5V at F7040 with fake charger?
But fluctuates with original charger?
If yes, then change <TRANSISTOR>Q7080</TRANSISTOR>/85.

Just in case, try to start in SMC bypass mode.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green light. No fan spin.
threads.message:
Changed both <TRANSISTOR>Q7080</TRANSISTOR>/85 and now 12.5v at F7040 seems to be more stable but i still find occasionally my multimeter will see it drop below 2v and bounced back (maybe it goes to zero but i think my multimeter is too slow), but voltage not as cycling as before. Fan still spin up and down.

Fake charger still stable at 12.5v at F7040, no fan spin on fake charger. (Just compared to another working <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> it seems this fake charger doesnt work on these 2850 boards. Just no fan spin!)

But in SMC bypass mode: both real and fake charger it is on with high spin fan [B]on and off[/B]....

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green light. No fan spin.
threads.message:
Fake charger has 85W cable?
If not, connect charged battery (plus charger) and press power button.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green light. No fan spin.
threads.message:
you mean i should not use real charger to troubleshoot this bad board now? 

I should use battery + fake charger to connect to this bad board now?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green light. No fan spin.
threads.message:
Yes, for test.
Original charger detects some leakage and that should be the cycling reason.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green light. No fan spin.
threads.message:
oh my fake charger is only 60W...

can i just connect battery + fake charger + short <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> to ground instead of a power switch? I dont have it mounted inside the case right now...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green light. No fan spin.
threads.message:
Of course, read this...
[URL unfurl="true"]https://boards.rossmanngroup.com/threads/how-to-collection.60974/[/URL]

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green light. No fan spin.
threads.message:
ok, i didnt have to short <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> to ground..

when i plug the battery, plug the fake 60w charger.. I see orange led and the fan still spin on and off...

i might have a psu somewhere but i havent really used one..should I try? 
(16.5v 4A will it work? i have a magsafe cable that i can hook it up to...)

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green light. No fan spin.
threads.message: You need 85W cable, if you want to test without battery.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green light. No fan spin.
threads.message:
ok i have hooked up that magsafe cable to the psu.. fan spin but with the same on and off pattern....

SMC bypass mode also the same, high speed fan on and off pattern...

I did compare diode mode values on big coil with a good board, all values seems value EXCEPT:
 L7530 on bad board is 140 and good board is 60

Is this a problem?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green light. No fan spin.
threads.message:
Board power cycles every 5s?
Which coils get voltage?
What about <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL>?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green light. No fan spin.
threads.message:
Yes, board power cycles every 5s. I can see from the PSU that it is drawing about 1A and then power cycle.

<SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> cycles with it between 0v and 3.3v

<SIGNAL>PPVCORE_S0_CPU</SIGNAL> cycles between 0 and 1.1v

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green light. No fan spin.
threads.message:
Do you get pulse at CPU coils too?
Also check <SIGNAL>PLT_RESET_L</SIGNAL>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green light. No fan spin.
threads.message:
I measured <SIGNAL>PPVCORE_S0_CPU</SIGNAL> at L7415/25. is that the CPU coils that you are talking about? 

<SIGNAL>PLT_RESET_L</SIGNAL> is cycling between 0 - 1v

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green light. No fan spin.
threads.message:
Yeah, there is VCORE.
If <SIGNAL>PLT_RESET_L</SIGNAL> pulses, then PCH detects that power on sequence is completed.
Could be a problem with GPU, or CPU.
GPU gets voltage pulse too (L8920)?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green light. No fan spin.
threads.message:
L8920 pulses between 0-0.9v

can I try to heat or reflow the CPU?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green light. No fan spin.
threads.message:
Change <CAPACITOR>C9560</CAPACITOR>, just in case.
Shouldn't be the culprit here, but is better to discard.
Do NOT use hot air...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green light. No fan spin.
threads.message:
<CAPACITOR>C9560</CAPACITOR> has been changed....

what now?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green light. No fan spin.
threads.message:
Did you use hot air in that area?

Lift L8920 and check if board stays on more time.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green light. No fan spin.
threads.message: no, it didnt stay on more time, it is the same.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green light. No fan spin.
threads.message:
Probably hopeless project...

Measure diode mode to ground on both side of series capacitors placed on the data lines batween CPU and GPU.
Look at page 74, many caps there...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green light. No fan spin.
threads.message: whooa...  you mean stuff like <CAPACITOR>C8020</CAPACITOR>/21/22 etc etc ?

threads.message: Yeah, that is...
